content: why? If there is an instance of the Ord class, it is possible to create an instance of LE or LT, since they are comparable, and it should be automatic.
I think there is a reason for this - please tell me why you don't want to automatically create instances of LE etc. from instances of the Ord class.

You can do attribute [local instance] leOfOrd if you like.

Creating instances like this automatically is dangerous. A type like Nat might want to implement LE, LT, Ord, BEq, etc., all separately to provide the most performant implementation for each. But if leOfOrd was a global instance, then there would be two instances of LE Nat which are not definitionally equal. This can lead to problems: if a function somewhere in the library only expects Ord as an argument but uses LE in its definition, then that will always use the leOfOrd instance, so it will use the wrong implementation of LE when called on a natural numbers. Even worse, if you apply a theorem about that function, you might end up with a goal about a ≤ b for natural numbers a and b but this is actuall the wrong ≤ so none of the theorems about inqualities of natural numbers will apply.

A better way to handle this would be for definitions to expect all of the instances independently and for theorems to expect Prop-valued typeclasses that express compatibilities between these instances. These typeclasses don't exist in Core at the moment, but Batteries has a few, like docs#Batteries.LawfulCmp. In the future, Core might introduce classes that are similar to these.
Asei Inoue has marked this topic as resolved.
